metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This case challenged the Trump Administration's authority to suspend federal funding to states becau...

target:
This case challenged the Trump Administration's authority to suspend federal funding to states because they continue to permit transgender girls and women to participate in women's school sports. On April 7, 2025, the state of Maine filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Agriculture in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine. On April 2, 2025, the Department of Agriculture froze funds allocated to Maine to feed schoolchildren because the federal government had determined that Maine was violating Title IX by continuing to permit transgender girls to participate in girls' school sports. Represented by the Maine Attorney General, the plaintiff alleged that the funding freeze violated the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"). The plaintiff asked the court to vacate and set aside the funding freeze and sought preliminary and permanent injunctive and declaratory relief. The case was assigned to District Judge John A. Woodcock.

The plaintiff filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) concurrently with the complaint. Judge Woodcock held a hearing on the TRO motion on April 8 and set a briefing schedule to conclude by April 10. Also on April 8, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint with slightly more detailed factual allegations and a statement of verification by the Assistant Attorney General of Maine.

On April 9, the court issued an order asking the parties to submit briefings regarding the court's jurisdiction. The court cited a recent Supreme Court opinion in a similar case, [../../../../case/46201/] suggesting that under the Tucker Act (28 U.S.C. § 1491), jurisdiction for suits based on "any express or implied contract with the United States" lies in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. Judge Woodcock asked the parties to address whether the District of Maine had jurisdiction, whether the Tucker Act provided exclusive jurisdiction in the Claims Court, and whether the Supreme Court's recent holding was distinguishable from this case.

The Court issued a TRO on April 11 ordering the defendant to unfreeze and release the frozen funds during the pendency of the TRO. On April 15, the parties filed a joint motion to extend the TRO past its 14 day term to May 9, 2025. Following a hearing on April 15, the court granted the extension motion and ordered the parties to propose a hearing date for the forthcoming preliminary injunction ("PI") motion by May 2.

The case then settled; according to press reports [https://www.foxnews.com/sports/maine-drops-trans-athlete-lawsuit-against-trump-administration-after-states-federal-funding-restored], USDA restored the challenged funding, and in exchange, Maine withdrew the lawsuit on May 2.

This case is closed.

On April 2, 2025, the Department of Agriculture froze funds allocated to Maine to feed schoolchildren because the federal government had determined that Maine was violating Title IX by continuing to permit transgender girls to participate in girls' school sports. Represented by the Maine Attorney General, the plaintiff alleged that the funding freeze violated the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"). The plaintiff asked the court to vacate and set aside the funding freeze and sought preliminary and permanent injunctive and declaratory relief. The case was assigned to District Judge John A. Woodcock.

Defendant: United States Department of Agriculture (federal executive agency)
April 2, 2025 – USDA froze funds earmarked for feeding Maine schoolchildren after finding Maine in violation of Title IX for allowing transgender girls to compete in girls’ sports.
April 7, 2025 – State of Maine filed suit against the USDA in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine challenging the funding freeze.
Background context – Dispute centered on whether the federal government could withhold school nutrition funds from states that allow transgender girls/women to compete in female school sports.

target:
This case challenged the Trump Administration's authority to suspend federal funding to states because they continue to permit transgender girls and women to participate in women's school sports. On April 7, 2025, the state of Maine filed this lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Agriculture in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maine. On April 2, 2025, the Department of Agriculture froze funds allocated to Maine to feed schoolchildren because the federal government had determined that Maine was violating Title IX by continuing to permit transgender girls to participate in girls' school sports. Represented by the Maine Attorney General, the plaintiff alleged that the funding freeze violated the Administrative Procedure Act ("APA"). The plaintiff asked the court to vacate and set aside the funding freeze and sought preliminary and permanent injunctive and declaratory relief. The case was assigned to District Judge John A. Woodcock.

The plaintiff filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) concurrently with the complaint. Judge Woodcock held a hearing on the TRO motion on April 8 and set a briefing schedule to conclude by April 10. Also on April 8, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint with slightly more detailed factual allegations and a statement of verification by the Assistant Attorney General of Maine.

On April 9, the court issued an order asking the parties to submit briefings regarding the court's jurisdiction. The court cited a recent Supreme Court opinion in a similar case, [../../../../case/46201/] suggesting that under the Tucker Act (28 U.S.C. § 1491), jurisdiction for suits based on "any express or implied contract with the United States" lies in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims. Judge Woodcock asked the parties to address whether the District of Maine had jurisdiction, whether the Tucker Act provided exclusive jurisdiction in the Claims Court, and whether the Supreme Court's recent holding was distinguishable from this case.

The Court issued a TRO on April 11 ordering the defendant to unfreeze and release the frozen funds during the pendency of the TRO. On April 15, the parties filed a joint motion to extend the TRO past its 14 day term to May 9, 2025. Following a hearing on April 15, the court granted the extension motion and ordered the parties to propose a hearing date for the forthcoming preliminary injunction ("PI") motion by May 2.

The case then settled; according to press reports [https://www.foxnews.com/sports/maine-drops-trans-athlete-lawsuit-against-trump-administration-after-states-federal-funding-restored], USDA restored the challenged funding, and in exchange, Maine withdrew the lawsuit on May 2.

This case is closed.

annotation.explanation: Temporary Restraining Order: April 11, 2025 – May 9, 2025
April 11, 2025: Temporary Restraining Order requiring USDA to unfreeze and release the funds.
April 15, 2025: Order extending the TRO to May 9, 2025, and directing parties to propose a PI hearing date.
April 11, 2025 – Court granted TRO compelling USDA to release the frozen funds while the order remained in effect.
April 15, 2025 – Parties jointly moved, and the court agreed, to extend the TRO to May 9 and to schedule a future preliminary-injunction hearing.
Joint motion to extend the TRO filed April 15, 2025
April 11, 2025 TRO: USDA must immediately unfreeze and release the previously frozen school-meal funds for the duration of the TRO.
April 15, 2025 Order: (a) TRO extended through May 9, 2025, keeping the funds unfrozen; (b) parties must file a proposed date for a preliminary-injunction hearing by May 2, 2025.
April 11, 2025 TRO: USDA must immediately unfreeze and release the previously frozen school-meal funds for Maine for the duration of the TRO.
April 15, 2025 order: (a) TRO extended through May 9, 2025; (b) both sides must submit a proposed preliminary-injunction hearing date by May 2, 2025.
Hearing on joint motion to extend TRO – April 15, 2025, before Judge John A. Woodcock (U.S. District Court for the District of Maine)
April 11, 2025 – Court granted plaintiff’s motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO), directing USDA to unfreeze and release the withheld funds.
April 15, 2025 – Court granted the parties’ joint motion to extend the TRO through May 9, 2025.
